nodes.name: EWU Official Course Catalog
nodes.description: Eastern Washington University's comprehensive academic catalog containing all officially offered courses across four colleges. Serves as the foundational source for degree requirements, course sequences, and academic standards for undergraduate and graduate programs.

nodes.name: College of Professional Programs (CPP)
nodes.description: Career-focused college offering professional education in business, education, and applied fields. Emphasizes practical skills development and industry partnerships for career preparation.

nodes.name: School of Psychology

cs_relevance.human_computer_interaction: Cognitive psychology and user behavior research essential for UX design
cs_relevance.research_methods: Statistical analysis and experimental design skills transferable to data science
cs_relevance.artificial_intelligence: Cognitive psychology principles inform AI and machine learning algorithms

special_programs.school_psychology_eds: Educational Specialist degree in School Psychology
special_programs.bellevue_campus: Psychology programs available at Bellevue Campus for working professionals
special_programs.sel_ee_certificate: Social Emotional Learning-Educational Equity Graduate Certificate

nodes.name: School of Libraries
nodes.description: Information science and library studies programs preparing professionals for modern library and information management roles with focus on digital literacy, community engagement, and information organization.

nodes.name: Interdisciplinary Studies
nodes.description: Flexible interdisciplinary programs allowing students to combine multiple fields of study, including organizational leadership, data analytics, children's studies, and other specialized professional concentrations.

nodes.name: School of Education
nodes.description: Teacher preparation and educational leadership programs designed to develop skilled educators and administrators with emphasis on practical experience, diversity awareness, and educational innovation.

nodes.name: School of Social Work
nodes.description: Professional social work education focusing on clinical practice, community organizing, policy advocacy, and social justice with field experience and preparation for licensure and advanced practice.

nodes.name: College of Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (CSTEM)
nodes.description: The College of Science, Technology, Engineering, & Mathematics prepares students to succeed in fields such as Biology, Chemistry, Computer Programming, Data Science, Geoscience, Web Design, and Computational Mathematics. Faculty actively engage in research providing students opportunities to participate in real-world projects.

official_metadata.mission: Primary mission is to prepare students for today's challenges and tomorrow's opportunities by working closely with students, providing courses that keep up with technological advancements, and working with the local community to solve problems.

dean.education: Bachelor's, Master's and Doctorate in Geology at University of Southern California

main_office.spokane_address: Catalyst Building, 601 E Riverside Avenue, Spokane, WA 99201
main_office.cheney_address: 319 Computing & Engineering Building, 1075 Washington Street, Cheney, WA 99004

nodes.name: Mechanical Engineering & Technology Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in mechanical engineering, applied technology, construction management, and manufacturing technology with hands-on engineering experience.

special_features.industry_connections: Classes taught by experienced professionals with backgrounds in research and production
special_features.hands_on_focus: High-quality, hands-on education combining classroom instruction with state-of-the-art labs
special_features.collaboration_emphasis: Teamwork and collaboration as core components of learning
special_features.transfer_support: Specialized transfer student support for credit evaluation and academic planning

nodes.name: Chemistry, Biochemistry, & Physics Department
nodes.description: Department offering comprehensive programs in chemistry, biochemistry, and physics, providing students with strong foundations in physical sciences and research opportunities.

professors.name: Jeffrey Rahn
professors.title: Professor

nodes.name: Biology Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in biological sciences, including undergraduate and graduate degrees focused on life sciences, ecological systems, and research-based learning experiences.

graduate_program_director.role: Master of Science in Biology program oversight

secretary_senior.role: Department administration, major declarations, advisor assignments
secretary_senior.name: Lisa Williams
secretary_senior.title: Secretary Senior

nodes.name: Design Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in interaction design, user experience design, web development, and visual communication with emphasis on human-centered design principles.

department_chair.background: BA in Graphic Design from University of Notre Dame, MFA in Graphic Design from University of Idaho. Professional experience includes freelancing in Boulder CO and Prescott AZ, in-house design at Grand Targhee Ski and Summer Resort, and working at Riddell Advertising and Design in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
department_chair.name: Melinda Breen
department_chair.title: Professor, Department Chair

lecturers.background: Studied architecture at Columbia University, creative writing at University of Montana, and cartooning. Published graphic novel 'Butcher Paper' and science-fiction novel 'The Obsoletes'. Logos, illustrations, and cartoons have appeared in The Inlander, Smoke Long Quarterly, Scablands Books, Okey Panky.
lecturers.name: Simeon Mills
lecturers.title: Lecturer

nodes.name: Computer Science & Electrical Engineering
nodes.description: Department offering programs in computer science, electrical engineering, cybersecurity, and related technologies, with emphasis on hands-on learning.

electrical_engineering.name: Saqer Alhloul
electrical_engineering.title: Professor, Director, Electrical & Computer Engineering Program

computer_science_graduate.name: Bojian Xu
computer_science_graduate.title: Professor & Computer Science Graduate Program Director

cybersecurity_graduate.name: Tony Espinoza
cybersecurity_graduate.title: Assistant Professor & Cybersecurity Graduate Program Director

nodes.name: Minor Programs
nodes.description: Supplementary programs allowing students to gain basic competency in computer science or electrical engineering while pursuing other majors.

nodes.name: Undergraduate Programs
nodes.description: Bachelor's degree programs in computer science and electrical engineering. Provides foundational education for entry-level technical careers and preparation for graduate studies.

nodes.name: BS–Computer Science Cyber Operations
nodes.description: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science Cyber Operations - specialized cybersecurity program offered in Spokane combining traditional computer science foundations with advanced cyber operations, digital forensics, and information security methodologies.

nodes.name: BS–Cyber Operations
nodes.description: Bachelor of Science in Cyber Operations - dedicated cybersecurity degree offered in Spokane emphasizing threat analysis, cyber defense strategies, incident response, and security operations. Designed for careers in information security and cyber defense operations.

nodes.name: BS–Electrical and Computer Engineering
nodes.description: Bachelor of Science in Electrical & Computer Engineering - integrated ABET-accredited program covering electrical engineering fundamentals and computer engineering applications. Offered in Spokane with comprehensive laboratory experiences and industry partnerships.

nodes.name: BCS–Computer Science
nodes.description: Bachelor of Computer Science - specialized computing degree offered in Spokane emphasizing practical programming skills, software development methodologies, and computing applications across disciplines. Designed for students seeking comprehensive technical competency.

nodes.name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BS-CS)
nodes.description: ABET-accredited comprehensive computer science program focusing on programming, algorithms, database systems, networking, software development, cybersecurity, computer architecture, operating systems, and computing ethics. Differs from BCS degree in mathematics and natural science requirements.

nodes.name: Required Computer Science Courses
nodes.description: Core computer science curriculum providing foundational knowledge in programming, data structures, algorithms, and software engineering. Represents the essential technical content for CS degree completion. Total of 61 credits across multiple course levels.

nodes.name: 200 Level Computer Science Courses
nodes.description: Intermediate computer science courses building upon programming fundamentals. Introduces object-oriented programming, system programming, and computer architecture concepts essential for advanced coursework.

official_course_metadata.course-notes: concurrent registration in MATH 142 or higher is highly recommended
official_course_metadata.official-catalog-description: This course continues coverage of concepts introduced in Programming Principles I. Topics include composition, recursion, data abstraction, polymorphism, inheritance, interfaces, inner classes, abstract classes, object cloning, array lists, linked lists, and exception handling. Programming projects are required.

nodes.name: CSCD 211: Programming Principles II
nodes.description: Continues coverage of concepts introduced in Programming Principles I. Students master composition, recursion, data abstraction, polymorphism, inheritance, interfaces, inner classes, abstract classes, object cloning, array lists, linked lists, and exception handling through required programming projects.

career_preparation: Software development using object-oriented design patterns
Implementation of data structures in enterprise applications
Code maintenance and extension through inheritance hierarchies
Error handling and robust software development practices
learning_objectives: Implement inheritance and polymorphism in Java programming projects
Design and implement linked lists and array lists with appropriate operations
Apply composition and aggregation relationships in object-oriented design
Solve problems using recursive algorithms and analyze their efficiency
Handle exceptions using try-catch blocks and custom exception classes
Create and implement interfaces and abstract classes for flexible design
Design inner classes and understand nested class relationships
Implement object cloning for deep and shallow copying scenarios

nodes.name: Data Structures and Collections
nodes.description: Implementation of array lists, linked lists, and object cloning in Java. Students learn to manipulate dynamic data structures, understand reference semantics, and implement deep vs. shallow copying for object management.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Understand dynamic data structures and memory management in object-oriented programming
nodes.career_relevance: Critical for algorithm implementation, data processing applications, and system programming

nodes.name: Linked List Implementation
nodes.description: Design and implementation of singly and doubly linked lists including node creation, pointer manipulation, and traversal algorithms. Students learn to manage dynamic memory allocation through references and implement fundamental linked data structure operations.
assessment_objectives: Implement linked list from scratch
Debug pointer-related issues
Choose between singly and doubly linked approaches

nodes.name: Object Cloning Techniques
nodes.description: Implementation of shallow and deep cloning for object copying including the Cloneable interface, clone() method overriding, and copy constructors. Students learn to manage object duplication while understanding reference semantics and memory allocation patterns.
assessment_objectives: Implement appropriate cloning strategy for given objects
Distinguish between shallow and deep copying needs
Handle cloning exceptions properly

nodes.name: ArrayList Operations & Implementation
nodes.description: Dynamic array manipulation using Java's ArrayList class including insertion, deletion, searching, and iteration. Students learn to work with resizable arrays and understand the performance characteristics of various operations on dynamic collections.
assessment_objectives: Implement ArrayList operations efficiently
Choose appropriate methods for specific tasks
Understand ArrayList performance characteristics

nodes.name: Collection Framework Basics
nodes.description: Introduction to Java's Collections Framework including common interfaces (Collection, List, Set) and their relationship to concrete implementations. Students learn to work with generic collections and understand the hierarchy that underlies Java's data structure library.
assessment_objectives: Use appropriate collection interfaces
Understand generic type safety
Apply iterator patterns correctly

nodes.name: Object-Oriented Design Principles
nodes.description: Core object-oriented programming concepts including data abstraction, polymorphism, and inheritance as implemented in Java. Students learn to design class hierarchies, implement polymorphic behavior, and apply encapsulation principles to create maintainable and extensible software.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Build fluency in object-oriented design and implementation using Java
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for software engineering roles requiring object-oriented design and enterprise Java development

nodes.name: Data Abstraction Techniques
nodes.description: Fundamental techniques for creating abstract data types that hide implementation details while exposing essential operations. Students learn to design classes that encapsulate data and provide controlled access through well-defined interfaces.
assessment_objectives: Design abstract data types with appropriate encapsulation
Implement information hiding in class design
Create controlled access interfaces

nodes.name: Inheritance Hierarchies
nodes.description: Design and implementation of class inheritance hierarchies including super/subclass relationships, inheritance types, and method inheritance. Students learn to create logical class hierarchies that promote code reuse and maintainability.
assessment_objectives: Design logical inheritance hierarchies
Implement proper super/subclass relationships
Apply appropriate inheritance patterns

nodes.name: Polymorphic Behavior Implementation
nodes.description: Implementation of polymorphic behavior through method overriding and dynamic binding. Students master runtime polymorphism to create flexible, extensible software systems that can work with objects of different types uniformly.
assessment_objectives: Implement method overriding correctly
Demonstrate understanding of dynamic binding
Create polymorphic object collections

atomic_concept.core_principle: Method resolution occurs at runtime based on actual object type
atomic_concept.timing: Binding decision deferred until program execution
atomic_concept.mechanism: Virtual method table lookup determines correct implementation

prerequisite_knowledge: Understanding of object instantiation from CSCD 210
Familiarity with reference variables vs. objects
nodes.name: Dynamic Binding Understanding
nodes.description: Comprehension of how the Java Virtual Machine determines which method implementation to execute at runtime based on the actual object type, not the reference type. Critical for understanding polymorphic behavior execution.
assessment_objectives: Predict which method implementation executes given inheritance hierarchy
Explain difference between compile-time and runtime method resolution
Trace virtual method dispatch through inheritance chains

nodes.atomic_concept: Java Language Specification Â§8.4.8 principle: all instance methods (except private, static, and final) use virtual dispatch, enabling late binding through virtual method table lookup at runtime
nodes.name: Virtual Method Usage
nodes.description: Implementation of Java's dynamic method dispatch mechanism as defined in JLS Â§15.12.4.4, where instance method invocations are resolved at runtime based on the actual class of the target object rather than the compile-time type of the reference.
assessment_criteria: Correctly predict method resolution using JLS Â§15.12.2.5 most specific method rules
Identify compile-time vs. runtime method binding scenarios according to JLS Â§8.4.8
Design inheritance hierarchies demonstrating proper virtual method override patterns
learning_objectives: Apply JLS Â§15.12.4.4 dynamic method dispatch rules to determine runtime method selection
Distinguish between methods eligible for virtual dispatch (instance methods) vs. direct binding (static, private, final)
Trace virtual method table lookup process for overridden methods in inheritance hierarchies
Analyze performance implications of virtual method calls vs. direct method invocation

atomic_concept.benefits: Code flexibility, extensibility, reduced conditional logic
atomic_concept.core_principle: Same method call produces different behavior based on object type
atomic_concept.implementation_pattern: Parent reference, child object, overridden methods

nodes.name: Runtime Polymorphism Implementation
nodes.description: Practical implementation of polymorphic systems where the same interface can exhibit different behaviors depending on the concrete object type at runtime. Enables flexible, extensible software architectures.
assessment_objectives: Implement polymorphic method calls using parent references
Create systems that work with multiple object types uniformly
Design extensible code using polymorphic patterns

nodes.atomic_concept: Java Collections Framework pattern: Collection<SuperType> containing subtype instances, where virtual method dispatch occurs during iteration per JLS Â§15.12.4.4 runtime method selection
nodes.name: Polymorphic Collections
nodes.description: Application of Java Collections Framework (JCF) design principles using Collection<E> interface hierarchy to store heterogeneous objects with common supertype, enabling polymorphic method dispatch during iteration as specified in Collections API documentation.
assessment_criteria: Correctly implement Collection<SuperType> holding diverse subtypes per JCF design patterns
Demonstrate virtual method dispatch during collection iteration following JLS Â§15.12.4.4
Apply appropriate Collection interface methods (add, remove, iterator) with polymorphic elements
learning_objectives: Implement Java Collections Framework pattern: List<Animal> holding Dog, Cat subtype instances with common interface
Apply enhanced for-loop iteration (JSR 201) over polymorphic collections triggering virtual method dispatch
Design collections using Java Generics (JSR 14) with bounded type parameters: Collection<? extends BaseType>
Analyze polymorphic behavior in collection algorithms demonstrating Liskov Substitution Principle compliance

nodes.atomic_concept: JLS Â§8.4.8.1 overriding requirements: identical method signature (name, parameter types, return type), compatible access modifiers, and exception specification compatibility with superclass method
nodes.name: Method Overriding Techniques
nodes.description: Implementation of JLS Â§8.4.8.1 method overriding rules including signature matching, access modifier constraints, exception compatibility, and proper use of @Override annotation for compile-time verification.
assessment_criteria: Correctly override methods following JLS signature matching requirements
Demonstrate proper @Override annotation usage preventing accidental overloading
Apply access modifier rules: overriding method cannot be more restrictive than overridden method
learning_objectives: Apply JLS Â§8.4.8.1 method overriding rules: identical signature with compatible return types and access modifiers
Use @Override annotation (JSR 175) for compile-time verification of proper method overriding
Implement super.methodName() calls to invoke superclass method implementations within overridden methods
Validate exception compatibility per JLS Â§8.4.8.3: overriding methods cannot declare broader checked exceptions

nodes.atomic_concept: JLS Â§15.20.2 instanceof operator combined with JLS Â§15.16 cast expressions to perform checked narrowing reference conversions, ensuring type safety at runtime
nodes.name: Type-Safe Casting
nodes.description: Implementation of JLS Â§15.20.2 instanceof operator and JLS Â§15.16 cast expressions for safe type narrowing conversions, preventing ClassCastException through runtime type checking before downcasting reference types.
assessment_criteria: Correctly apply instanceof-then-cast pattern following JLS Â§5.5 casting conversion rules
Demonstrate understanding of compile-time vs. runtime type checking per JLS Â§15.16.1
Show proper exception handling for invalid cast attempts per JLS Â§15.16
learning_objectives: Apply JLS Â§15.20.2 instanceof operator to verify object type before performing narrowing reference conversions
Execute JLS Â§15.16 cast expressions safely using pattern: if (obj instanceof Type) { Type t = (Type)obj; }
Distinguish between widening conversions (automatic) and narrowing conversions (requiring explicit cast)
Implement defensive programming patterns preventing ClassCastException in polymorphic systems

nodes.name: Encapsulation Mechanisms
nodes.description: Implementation of encapsulation through access modifiers, getter/setter methods, and class boundaries. Students master the practical application of encapsulation principles to create well-structured, maintainable object-oriented code.
assessment_objectives: Apply access modifiers appropriately
Implement proper getter/setter methods
Design clean public interfaces

nodes.name: Advanced Programming Techniques
nodes.description: Advanced programming techniques including recursion, composition patterns, and exception handling in Java. Students implement recursive algorithms, design object composition relationships, and create robust error handling using try-catch mechanisms.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Master advanced programming techniques for solving complex computational problems
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for algorithm development, system robustness, and complex software architecture

nodes.name: Exception Handling Strategies
nodes.description: Comprehensive error management using Java's exception handling mechanism including try-catch blocks, finally clauses, custom exception design, and exception propagation. Students learn to build robust applications that gracefully handle error conditions and provide meaningful feedback.
assessment_objectives: Implement robust exception handling
Design appropriate custom exceptions
Manage resources safely with exceptions

nodes.name: Recursive Problem Solving
nodes.description: Design and implementation of recursive algorithms including base case identification, recursive case formulation, and stack frame analysis. Students learn to break complex problems into smaller self-similar subproblems and understand the relationship between recursion and mathematical induction.
assessment_objectives: Design correct recursive algorithms
Debug recursive stack overflow issues
Choose between recursive and iterative approaches

nodes.name: Object Composition Patterns
nodes.description: Design patterns using object composition to build complex functionality from simpler components. Students learn to prefer composition over inheritance, implement has-a relationships, and create flexible object architectures that promote code reuse and maintainability.
assessment_objectives: Design effective composition relationships
Choose composition over inheritance appropriately
Implement loosely coupled systems

nodes.name: Interface and Contract Design
nodes.description: Design and implementation of interfaces, abstract classes, and inner classes in Java. Students create behavioral contracts through interfaces, implement template patterns with abstract classes, and organize code using nested class structures.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Learn to design flexible software architectures using Java's interface and abstract class mechanisms
nodes.career_relevance: Fundamental for API design, framework development, and maintainable enterprise applications

nodes.name: Interface Design & Implementation
nodes.description: Creation and implementation of Java interfaces to define contracts between software components. Students learn to design clean APIs, implement multiple interfaces, and use interfaces to achieve polymorphism and loose coupling in object-oriented systems.
assessment_objectives: Design clear interface contracts
Implement interfaces correctly
Use interfaces for polymorphic behavior

nodes.name: Abstract Class Design Patterns
nodes.description: Design and implementation of abstract classes to provide partial implementations and enforce class hierarchies. Students learn when to choose abstract classes over interfaces, implement template method patterns, and create extensible class architectures with shared behavior.
assessment_objectives: Choose between abstract classes and interfaces appropriately
Implement template method patterns
Design effective class hierarchies

nodes.name: Inner Class Architectures
nodes.description: Implementation of nested, inner, and anonymous classes to create sophisticated object relationships and encapsulation patterns. Students learn to use inner classes for helper functionality, event handling, and creating tightly coupled component relationships.
assessment_objectives: Implement appropriate inner class types
Use inner classes for encapsulation
Create anonymous classes for interfaces

nodes.description: Foundational programming course covering information representation, algorithms, and program design. Establishes systematic approach to problem-solving through programming and introduces essential software development practices.
nodes.name: CSCD 210: Programming Principles I
nodes.official-catalog-description: This course covers the concepts and practices of information representation, computer algorithms, hardware organization and computer program design and implementation. Students write, run, debug, analyze and evaluate computer programs. Topics include primitive data types, number systems, file I/O classes, control structures, method design and usage, array–sorting and searching algorithms. Programming projects are required.

nodes.name: File I/O Operations & Data Persistence
nodes.description: File input/output operations for reading from and writing to external files. Students learn to work with file streams, handle file-based data, and implement data persistence solutions for programs that need to save and retrieve information.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Enable programs to work with external data sources and save program state
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for data processing applications and persistent storage systems

pedagogical_notes: Students often struggle with file path concepts and exception handling
Emphasize the importance of closing file resources
Practice with various file formats builds practical skills
Common errors include file not found and data format mismatches
nodes.description: Atomic skill for reading and parsing data from files using Java I/O classes and methods
practical_applications: Reading configuration files in applications
Processing data files for analysis
Importing user data from external sources
Loading game state or user preferences
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate creation of File objects for input operations
Implement proper exception handling for file input operations
Show proficiency in reading various data types from files
Parse and process structured file formats correctly
Apply input validation techniques during file reading
nodes.title: File Input Processing
atomic_skills: Scanner class usage with file input streams
Exception handling with try-catch blocks for IOException
Data type conversion during file reading
learning_objectives: Create File and Scanner objects for file input
Implement exception handling for file not found scenarios
Read different data types from text files using appropriate Scanner methods
Parse structured data formats from files (CSV, space-delimited)
Validate input data during file reading operations

pedagogical_notes: Students need practice with format specifiers for proper output formatting
Emphasize the importance of closing output streams to ensure data is written
Common mistakes include forgetting to flush buffers and improper formatting
Demonstrate file overwrite vs. append modes
nodes.description: Atomic skill for writing and formatting data to files using Java I/O classes and methods
practical_applications: Generating reports from program data
Saving user preferences and application state
Creating log files for debugging and monitoring
Exporting data for use in other applications
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate creation of PrintWriter objects for output operations
Apply proper formatting techniques for file output
Implement exception handling for file writing scenarios
Generate well-formatted structured output files
Show understanding of file creation and overwrite policies
nodes.title: File Output Generation
atomic_skills: PrintWriter class instantiation for file output
Formatted output using printf with format specifiers
Exception handling for file writing operations
learning_objectives: Create PrintWriter objects for file output operations
Format data for output to text files using printf and println methods
Implement proper file writing with exception handling
Generate structured output formats (CSV, formatted reports)
Manage file creation and overwrite behaviors
career_relevance: Log file creation for system monitoring
Data export functionality in enterprise systems

pedagogical_notes: Students need to understand the relationship between memory and persistent storage
Emphasize the importance of data format consistency across save/load cycles
Practice with different data structures (arrays, objects) builds understanding
Common issues include data format mismatches and incomplete state restoration
nodes.description: Atomic skill for implementing strategies to save and restore program state using file-based persistence
practical_applications: Saving game progress and user preferences
Application configuration management
Data backup and recovery systems
Session state preservation in web applications
assessment_objectives: Design appropriate data formats for persistence requirements
Implement complete save/load cycles for program state
Demonstrate data integrity validation techniques
Apply error handling for persistence operation failures
Show understanding of data format versioning considerations
nodes.title: Data Persistence Patterns
atomic_skills: Object state serialization to text format
Data integrity validation during load operations
Error recovery for corrupted persistence files
learning_objectives: Design data structures suitable for file-based persistence
Implement save/load functionality for program objects
Apply serialization techniques for basic data types
Create checkpoint and recovery mechanisms
Handle data integrity during persistence operations

pedagogical_notes: Students often forget to close streams, leading to resource leaks
Try-with-resources is a more advanced concept that prevents common mistakes
Emphasize the cost of unclosed resources in system performance
Practice with both manual and automatic resource management patterns
nodes.description: Atomic skill for proper management of I/O streams including resource allocation, usage, and cleanup
practical_applications: Efficient file processing in large-scale applications
Memory-conscious I/O operations in resource-constrained environments
Robust error handling in production file operations
Performance optimization for high-throughput data processing
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate proper stream opening and closing procedures
Implement try-with-resources for automatic resource cleanup
Apply appropriate exception handling for stream operations
Show understanding of resource management best practices
Optimize stream usage for different file operation scenarios
nodes.title: Stream Management
atomic_skills: Exception handling specific to stream operations
learning_objectives: Understand the concept of I/O streams and resource management
Implement proper stream opening and closing patterns
Apply try-with-resources for automatic resource management
Handle stream exceptions and error conditions
Optimize stream usage for performance and memory efficiency
career_relevance: Embedded systems programming with limited resources

nodes.name: Control Structures & Program Flow
nodes.description: Systematic control of program execution through conditional statements, loops, and methods. Students learn to implement decision-making logic, repetitive operations, and modular program design through proper use of control structures.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Develop systematic approach to controlling program execution and logic flow
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for algorithm implementation and software logic design

nodes.name: Loop Structure Design & Implementation
nodes.description: Design and implementation of repetitive operations using for, while, and do-while loops. Students learn to choose appropriate loop structures, control loop execution, and implement iterative algorithms with proper termination conditions.
assessment_objectives: Choose appropriate loop structure for given problems
Implement correct loop termination logic
Debug common loop errors

nodes.name: Method Design & Usage Patterns
nodes.description: Design and implementation of methods for modular program organization including parameter passing, return values, and method decomposition. Students learn to break complex problems into manageable method-based solutions with proper encapsulation.
assessment_objectives: Design methods with appropriate signatures
Implement effective parameter passing
Apply method decomposition to complex problems

nodes.name: Conditional Logic Implementation
nodes.description: Design and implementation of decision-making structures using if, else if, else statements, switch cases, and boolean logic. Students learn to create programs that respond appropriately to different conditions and user inputs.
assessment_objectives: Implement correct conditional logic
Choose appropriate conditional structures
Debug logical errors in conditions

nodes.name: Program Flow Control & Execution
nodes.description: Understanding and controlling program execution flow including break, continue, return statements, and method call sequences. Students learn to manage program control flow for efficient and readable code organization.
assessment_objectives: Use flow control statements appropriately
Debug execution flow issues
Design clear program execution paths

nodes.name: Arrays & Algorithm Fundamentals
nodes.description: Array manipulation techniques and fundamental algorithms including sorting and searching. Students learn to work with collections of data, implement basic algorithms, and understand algorithmic thinking and efficiency considerations.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Develop systematic approach to data organization and algorithmic problem-solving
nodes.career_relevance: Foundation for data structures, algorithm design, and performance optimization

nodes.name: Searching Algorithm Design
nodes.description: Implementation of linear and binary search algorithms for finding elements in arrays. Students learn systematic search strategies, understand when to use different search approaches, and analyze search algorithm efficiency.
assessment_objectives: Implement both linear and binary search
Choose appropriate search algorithm
Handle search edge cases correctly

nodes.name: Basic Algorithm Analysis
nodes.description: Introduction to algorithm efficiency analysis including time and space complexity concepts. Students learn to evaluate algorithm performance, understand Big-O notation basics, and make informed decisions about algorithm selection.
assessment_objectives: Analyze basic algorithm efficiency
Compare algorithm performance
Understand complexity trade-offs

nodes.name: Sorting Algorithm Implementation
nodes.description: Implementation of fundamental sorting algorithms including bubble sort, selection sort, and insertion sort. Students learn algorithmic thinking, step-by-step algorithm design, and understand trade-offs between different sorting approaches.
assessment_objectives: Implement basic sorting algorithms correctly
Compare algorithm efficiency
Debug sorting algorithm issues

nodes.name: Array Manipulation Techniques
nodes.description: Fundamental array operations including creation, initialization, traversal, and modification. Students learn to work with one-dimensional and multi-dimensional arrays, understand index-based access, and implement array-based algorithms.
assessment_objectives: Implement correct array operations
Handle array bounds safely
Design efficient array traversal algorithms

nodes.name: Programming Fundamentals
nodes.description: Core programming concepts including primitive data types, number systems, and information representation. Students learn foundational programming skills including variable management, basic I/O operations, and understanding how computers represent and manipulate different types of data.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Establish fundamental understanding of how computers store and manipulate data
nodes.career_relevance: Essential foundation for all programming and software development work

nodes.name: Variable Scope & Lifetime Management
nodes.description: Understanding variable scope rules, lifetime, and accessibility within different program contexts including local, instance, and class variables. Students learn proper variable naming, scope boundaries, and memory management principles.
assessment_objectives: Determine variable accessibility in different contexts
Choose appropriate variable scope for given scenarios
Implement proper variable naming practices

nodes.name: Basic Input/Output Operations
nodes.description: Fundamental input and output operations using System.out for output and Scanner for input. Students learn to interact with users through console-based programs, handle different input types, and format output appropriately.
assessment_objectives: Implement basic console I/O operations
Handle different input data types safely
Create user-friendly program interfaces

nodes.name: Number Systems & Data Representation
nodes.description: Understanding how computers represent numbers and data using binary, decimal, and hexadecimal number systems. Students learn conversion between number systems, binary arithmetic, and how different data types are stored in computer memory.
assessment_objectives: Convert between number systems accurately
Understand binary arithmetic operations
Explain how computers store different data types

nodes.name: Primitive Data Types & Variables
nodes.description: Understanding and usage of Java's primitive data types including int, double, boolean, char, and their characteristics. Students learn variable declaration, initialization, type conversion, and the differences between primitive and reference types.
assessment_objectives: Choose appropriate data types for given scenarios
Implement correct variable declarations
Perform safe type conversions

nodes.description: System programming using C language and Unix environment. Covers development tools, file systems, system calls, and low-level programming concepts. Bridges high-level programming with system-level understanding.
nodes.name: CSCD 240: C and Unix Programming
nodes.official-catalog-description: This course includes program development tools of the UNIX operating system and syntax and programming techniques of the C language in that environment. UNIX topics include interactive shells, common text editors, utility programs, file system structure, libraries and operating system calls and system programming. C topics include data types, structures, pointers and pointer arithmetic, arrays, linked lists, and function design and use. Programming projects are required.

nodes.name: C Language Programming Fundamentals
nodes.description: Core C programming language concepts including data types, structures, function design and use. Emphasizes C-specific programming patterns and low-level programming techniques essential for system-level software development.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Master foundational C programming skills and understand procedural programming paradigms
nodes.career_relevance: Foundation for systems programming, embedded development, operating systems, and performance-critical applications

pedagogical_notes: Students transitioning from Java often struggle with explicit memory management
Struct vs. class concepts require careful explanation
Memory alignment and padding are often surprising to students
Bit manipulation requires practice with binary arithmetic
Visual diagrams of memory layout help understanding
nodes.description: Atomic skill for mastering C-specific data types, struct definitions, and low-level data organization principles for systems programming
practical_applications: System programming requiring efficient data organization
Hardware interface programming with specific data formats
Network programming with protocol-specific data structures
Embedded systems with memory-constrained environments
assessment_objectives: Select appropriate C data types for specific programming requirements
Design efficient data structures using structs and unions
Implement bit-level operations for system programming tasks
Apply typedef effectively for code organization and abstraction
Demonstrate understanding of memory layout and alignment issues
nodes.title: C Data Types and Structures
atomic_skills: Primitive data type selection and memory size considerations
Structure definition, initialization, and member access
Union usage for shared memory storage
Typedef declarations for code readability and abstraction
Bit manipulation and bit field operations
learning_objectives: Understand primitive C data types and their memory representations
Design and implement custom structures for data organization
Apply unions for memory-efficient data storage
Use typedef for creating custom data type abstractions
Implement bit-level operations and bit fields for hardware interaction
career_relevance: Systems programming and operating system development
Embedded systems development with hardware constraints
Game engine development requiring performance optimization

pedagogical_notes: Memory management is one of the most challenging aspects for students
Pointer arithmetic requires careful attention to detail and practice
Memory leaks and segmentation faults are common debugging challenges
Visual aids and memory diagrams are essential for understanding
nodes.description: Domain covering low-level memory management and data structure implementation in C, including pointers, dynamic allocation, and manual memory management
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate safe and efficient pointer usage
Implement dynamic data structures without memory leaks
Apply appropriate memory allocation strategies
Debug memory-related errors using tools like valgrind
nodes.title: Memory and Data Structures
learning_objectives: Master pointer arithmetic and pointer-to-pointer concepts
Implement dynamic memory allocation using malloc and free
Build linked data structures with manual memory management
Apply memory debugging techniques and tools
Understand memory layout and address space concepts
career_relevance: Systems programming and operating system development
Embedded systems with limited memory resources

pedagogical_notes: Pointer arithmetic is one of the most challenging concepts for students
Visual memory diagrams are essential for understanding
Common errors include off-by-one mistakes and null pointer dereferencing
Practice with simple examples before moving to complex scenarios
Debugging tools like gdb and valgrind are essential for learning
nodes.description: Atomic skill for understanding and implementing pointer arithmetic operations, address manipulation, and pointer-to-pointer concepts in C programming
practical_applications: Efficient array and string manipulation algorithms
Implementation of dynamic data structures
Memory-efficient programming in resource-constrained environments
System-level programming and driver development
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate safe pointer arithmetic without buffer overruns
Implement complex pointer manipulations for data structure operations
Apply pointer arithmetic for efficient array and string processing
Debug and fix pointer arithmetic errors using appropriate tools
Show understanding of pointer arithmetic impact on memory layout
nodes.title: Pointer Arithmetic Mastery
prerequisite_skills: Basic C data types and variable concepts
Array concepts from previous programming courses
atomic_skills: Address calculation and pointer offset operations
Pointer increment, decrement, and comparison operations
Pointer arithmetic in function parameters and return values
learning_objectives: Understand memory addresses and pointer relationships
Perform arithmetic operations on pointers safely and efficiently
Implement pointer-to-pointer constructs for complex data structures
Apply pointer arithmetic for array traversal and manipulation
Debug pointer-related errors and memory access violations
career_relevance: Embedded systems programming with limited memory

nodes.name: Unix Operating System Environment
nodes.description: Comprehensive introduction to Unix/Linux system fundamentals including interactive shells, text editors, utility programs, and file system structure. Students master essential Unix tools and understand how operating systems provide development environments.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Establish proficiency with Unix development environment and system interaction paradigms
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for system administration, DevOps, server development, and most professional software development environments

pedagogical_notes: Students often struggle with command syntax and case sensitivity
Practice with real-world scenarios builds confidence
Common mistakes include incorrect path specifications and permission issues
Visual feedback from commands helps reinforce learning
nodes.description: Atomic skill for proficient use of Unix shell environments including command execution, environment variables, and shell scripting basics
practical_applications: Development environment setup and configuration
Build automation and deployment scripts
System administration tasks
DevOps and continuous integration workflows
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate proficiency with essential Unix commands
Configure shell environment for development workflows
Create simple shell scripts for task automation
Apply command-line tools for file and process management
Troubleshoot common shell interaction issues
nodes.title: Shell Interaction Mastery
learning_objectives: Execute commands effectively in bash and other Unix shells
Manage environment variables and shell configuration
Use command-line arguments and options efficiently
Apply basic shell scripting for automation
Navigate and manipulate the shell environment

pedagogical_notes: System programming requires understanding of both C language and Unix concepts
Students often struggle with the abstraction gap between high-level and system programming
Debugging system programs requires different tools and techniques
Error handling is critical as system errors can be difficult to diagnose
nodes.description: Domain covering system-level programming concepts including system calls, process management, and interaction with the operating system kernel through C programming interfaces
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate proficiency with common system calls
Implement process creation and communication
Apply file system operations at the system level
Handle system signals appropriately
nodes.title: System Programming
prerequisite_skills: Basic understanding of operating system concepts
learning_objectives: Understand the relationship between user space and kernel space
Implement system calls for file and process operations
Apply process creation and management techniques
Handle system signals and interrupts
Debug system-level programming errors

pedagogical_notes: System calls represent a significant conceptual leap from high-level programming
Error handling is critical as system call failures can be subtle
Students often confuse library functions with actual system calls
Practice with strace and other debugging tools helps understanding
Emphasize the performance implications of system call overhead
nodes.description: Atomic skill for understanding and implementing system calls to interact with the Unix kernel for file operations, process control, and system resource management
practical_applications: Low-level file manipulation for performance-critical applications
Process management in system administration tools
Implementation of custom shells and process managers
Development of system monitoring and logging tools
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate proper use of file operation system calls
Implement process creation and management using system calls
Apply appropriate error handling for system call failures
Show understanding of file descriptors and their management
Create programs that effectively utilize system call interfaces
nodes.title: System Call Interfaces
prerequisite_skills: C language fundamentals including pointers and functions
Basic understanding of operating system concepts
File I/O concepts from previous programming courses
atomic_skills: File descriptor management with open/close system calls
Data transfer using read/write system calls
Process creation and control with fork/exec family
System call parameter passing and return value processing
learning_objectives: Understand the system call interface and kernel/user space boundary
Implement file operations using system calls (open, read, write, close)
Apply process control system calls (fork, exec, wait)
Handle system call errors and return values appropriately
Use system calls for inter-process communication and synchronization
career_relevance: Operating system development and kernel programming
Embedded systems development with direct hardware interaction
DevOps tools and system administration utilities

nodes.description: Introduction to software engineering principles, methodologies, and practices for developing large-scale software systems. Covers software development lifecycle, requirements analysis, design patterns, testing strategies, and project management.
nodes.name: CSCD 260: Software Engineering
nodes.official-catalog-description: This course introduces students to software engineering principles and practices for developing large-scale software systems. Topics include software development lifecycle models, requirements engineering, software design and architecture, testing strategies, version control, and project management. Students work on team-based projects applying software engineering methodologies.

pedagogical_notes: Students often underestimate the importance of process in software development
Hands-on experience with team projects reinforces theoretical concepts
Version control conflicts are common learning opportunities
Agile practices require mindset shift from individual to team-oriented development
nodes.description: Domain covering systematic approaches to software development including methodologies, version control, project management, and team collaboration practices
assessment_objectives: Demonstrate proficiency with agile development practices
Implement branching strategies and collaborative workflows
Create realistic project plans with accurate time estimates
Apply team collaboration tools effectively in group projects
nodes.title: Software Development Lifecycle
learning_objectives: Understand various software development lifecycle models
Apply agile methodologies and practices in team projects
Implement effective version control strategies using Git
Plan and estimate software projects using proven techniques
Utilize collaboration tools for distributed team development
career_relevance: Essential for all professional software development roles
Project management and team leadership positions
Scrum master and agile coach positions

nodes.description: Exploration of computing technologies from socio-cultural and ethical perspectives, examining impacts on individuals, organizations, and society. Essential for developing responsible computing practices and understanding technology's broader implications.
nodes.name: CSCD 202: Computing Ethics
nodes.official-catalog-description: This course explores the uses of computing technologies from a socio-cultural and ethical perspective, including the impacts of information systems on individuals, organization, and society and future direction in which the forces of technology and computing are tending to move us.

nodes.name: Ethical Frameworks in Computing
nodes.description: Fundamental ethical theories and frameworks applied to computing contexts. Students explore deontological, consequentialist, and virtue ethics approaches to analyze moral dimensions of technology decisions, professional codes of conduct, and responsibility in computing practice.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Establish theoretical foundation for ethical analysis of computing technologies and professional practice
nodes.career_relevance: Essential for ethical decision-making in software development, data management, and technology leadership roles

nodes.name: Future Technology Implications
nodes.description: Analysis of emerging technologies and their potential societal trajectories. Students examine current technology trends, predict future developments, and consider proactive approaches to responsible innovation and technology governance.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Develop forward-thinking perspective on technology development and long-term consequence consideration
nodes.career_relevance: Valuable for technology strategy, research and development, and policy work in emerging technology fields

nodes.name: Technology Impact Analysis
nodes.description: Systematic examination of how information systems affect individuals, organizations, and society. Students learn to identify, analyze, and evaluate both positive and negative consequences of computing technologies across multiple scales and contexts.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Develop analytical skills for comprehensive evaluation of technology effects across multiple stakeholder groups
nodes.career_relevance: Critical for product managers, system designers, and technology policy professionals

nodes.name: Socio-Cultural Perspectives on Technology
nodes.description: Exploration of how cultural, social, and economic factors shape technology development and adoption. Addresses digital divide, accessibility, inclusion, privacy, and cultural values in computing system design and deployment.
nodes.pedagogical_purpose: Broaden understanding of technology as a socially embedded practice with diverse cultural implications
nodes.career_relevance: Important for user experience design, international development, and inclusive technology creation

nodes.name: Required Computer Science Electives
nodes.description: Six elective courses to customize education based on student interests and career goals. At least four courses must be 400-level. Covers specializations including graphics, AI/ML, cybersecurity, web development, game development, and embedded systems.

nodes.name: Required Supporting Courses
nodes.description: Foundational courses in cybersecurity, electrical engineering, and mathematics that support computer science education. Includes CYBR 101, EENG 160/160L, and mathematics sequence through discrete mathematics and statistics.

nodes.name: Required Senior Capstone Series
nodes.description: Two-course culminating experience that integrates computer science knowledge through substantial project work. Students demonstrate mastery of software engineering principles, technical communication, and problem-solving skills in a real-world context.

nodes.name: Required Laboratory Science Sequence
nodes.description: Students must choose one complete laboratory science sequence from Biology, Chemistry, Geosciences, or Physics. Provides scientific foundation and laboratory experience essential for computational modeling and scientific computing applications.

nodes.name: Graduate Programs
nodes.description: Master's and doctoral programs offering advanced study in computer science and electrical engineering. Emphasizes research, specialization, and professional development.

nodes.name: Geosciences Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in earth sciences, environmental science, geography, geology, and GIS with emphasis on field-based learning and environmental applications.

main_office.address: 1175 Washington St., Science Building 124, Cheney, WA 99004

special_programs.state_geology_license_prep: Focused on preparing graduates for the state geologist license required for most states
special_programs.scholarships: Weissenborn family and community scholarships available

special_programs.usgs_collaboration: One of the very few universities in the nation to place paid student employees with the US Geological Survey to assist with Mineral Resource projects

nodes.name: Mathematics Department

nodes.name: College of Health Science & Public Health (CHSPH)
nodes.description: Professional college focused on health sciences, public health, and medical education. Offers programs in nursing, health informatics, and community health with emphasis on evidence-based practice.

nodes.name: Nursing Department

nodes.name: Physical Therapy Department

nodes.name: Dental Hygiene Department
nodes.description: Department offering undergraduate programs in dental hygiene with emphasis on preventive oral health care, clinical skills, and community health promotion.

nodes.name: Public Health & Wellness & Movement Sciences Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in public health, exercise science, and wellness with emphasis on population health, fitness, and health promotion.

nodes.name: Communication Sciences & Disorders Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in speech-language pathology and audiology with emphasis on clinical practice, research, and evidence-based treatment approaches.

nodes.name: History, Anthropology & Modern Languages and Literatures Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in history, anthropology, and modern languages with emphasis on cultural understanding, historical analysis, and global perspectives.

nodes.name: Interdisciplinary Studies Department
nodes.description: Department offering interdisciplinary programs including Gender, Women's & Sexuality Studies, Military Science, and other cross-disciplinary academic programs.

nodes.name: Political Science & Public Policy Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in political science, public administration, and urban and regional planning with emphasis on governance, policy analysis, and civic engagement.

nodes.name: Fine & Performing Arts Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in art, music, theatre, and visual arts with emphasis on creative expression, artistic technique, and cultural understanding.

nodes.name: Sociology & Justice Studies Department
nodes.description: Department offering programs in sociology, criminology, and justice studies with emphasis on social analysis, criminal justice systems, and community engagement.
